Award.AwardTitle: IRES: Application of Biochemistry and Analytical Chemistry for Real-World Tasks in Ppublic Health and Biomedicine
Award.AbstractNarration:
This IRES award will provide research experiences to undergraduate students from Western Kentucky University (WKU) in South Korea at Pusan National University and Changwon National University. The WKU students will work on projects in biochemistry and analytical chemistry with the PI or Co-PI and respective South Korean collaborators. The PI, Professor Moon-Soo Kim from WKU, and Professor Haesik Yang from Pusan National University will collaborate on the use of sequence-specific Zinc Finger Proteins (ZFPs) and Transcriptional Activator-Like Effectors (TALEs) for the detection of pathogens. They seek improvements in detection sensitivity for this technique by using electrochemical detection with redox cycling. The development of a point-of-care diagnostic for pathogen detection is expected from this project. The Co-Pi, Professor Eric Conte from WKU, and Professor Yong-Ill Lee from Changwon National University will collaborate on the use of Magnetic Zirconia particles for the separation of chiral racemic drug mixtures. The separation of chiral racemic mixtures is a challenge in biomedicine where typically only one enantiomer will have biological activity. Magnetic zirconia particles show promise for separating a number of important racemic mixtures and subsequent isolation of the biologically important chiral molecule. Separating and isolating the pharmaceutically active chiral substance is important for studying a drug?s metabolic route.

A strengthened joint collaboration, involving WKU undergraduate students, will result between the WKU investigators from a predominately undergraduate institution and Korean collaborators at two internationally recognized Ph.D. granting institutions (Pusan and Changwon National Universities). In addition, this experience is designed to expose students to education within a different cultural milieu. They will gain an appreciation for higher education in a country other than their own and gain research experience in an international environment. Also, a greater cultural appreciation will result. WKU students will work in the laboratory of the PI or Co-PI during the academic year and visit their host Korean University during the summertime. Qualified underrepresented students from WKU will be given priority for this overseas visit, including students from nearby Appalachian counties. These students will be least likely to have the means to visit a foreign land and in general lack exposure to diverse cultures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Proposed is a collaborative agreement between faculty from WKU and South Korea with expertise in the areas of biochemistry and analytical chemistry, which focuses on extended international research experiences for WKU students. This enhanced the visibility of WKU as a leading university with international reach.  Dr. Moon-Soo Kim (PI) and Dr. Eric Conte (co-PI) traveled to Korea in the summers along with our students for this NSF program and mentored our students in Korea. The NSF-IRES students spent 8-10 weeks in Korea and gained advanced research skills and knowledge at Ph.D.-granting international settings along with an appreciation of foreign culture.

This grant supported international collaboration, involving WKU undergraduate and Gatton Academy students.  The PI?s collaborative project enabled us to develop a novel sensing technology utilizing engineered DNA-binding proteins in combination with an electrochemical detection method and new surface chemistry.  The co-PI?s collaborative approach allowed for a simple yet efficient means to isolate and quantify the pharmaceutically active chiral substance.  

A strengthened joint collaboration resulted between the WKU investigators from a predominately undergraduate institution and Korean collaborators at internationally recognized Ph.D. granting institutions.  In addition, this experience was designed to expose students to education within a different cultural milieu.  The NSF-IRES students gained an appreciation for higher education in a country other than their own and research experience in an international environment. Also, a greater cultural appreciation resulted since we promoted cultural experiences for our students during their stay in Korea.  The NSF-IRES students gave presentations on their collaborative projects in our collaborators? lab meetings, communicating with the Korean lab mates and supervisor and gaining the feedback on their research.  In addition to working with counterparts in the lab, this experience helped the NSF-IRES students strengthen their interaction skills in an international setting. We disseminated the results of collaborative research at regional and national meetings and through peer-viewed publications. This unique experience encouraged the NSF-IRES students to be actively engaged in advanced research and pursue an advanced degree for their career in sciences.  As a result, the participating students benefit greatly from this opportunity. 

Additionally, the PI organized NSF-IRES participants to share their experience from Korea with WKU students as the International Year of South Korea (IYOSK) event on campus in Fall 2016.This was a great way of ensuring WKU students having experienced and learned about other perspectives and cultures. This event is the only activities out of other IYOSK activities, which involves students who have actually travelled to Korea. Thus, this event made a unique contribution by focusing on international experience both in science and culture by students.
